The Open Source Planning Initiative supports innovation, development, and sharing in open source urban planning software. This foundation was formed out of an on-going need identified by urban planning practitioners across the nation to focus on innovation rather than rebuilding the same tools over and over again. This foundation will serve as an independent legal entity to which community members can contribute code, funding, and other resources, secure in the knowledge that their contributions will be maintained for public benefit.

We are a group of individuals mainly in the field often referred to as "Travel Demand Modeling". Most of us work for public agencies who are in charge of local or regional policy or funding decisions related to transportation (and land use, as it relates to transportation).

Collectively, we are broadly interested in getting better tools and information to planners, decision makers, and the public, quicker and more efficiently.





Activities

Methods

Clearinghouse of innovative planning methods that can be applied across the country.

Infrastructure

Provide critical infrastructure – legal, funding, hosting – to support the development of innovative planning tools.

Public Domain

Ensure advanced planning tools will remain in the public domain under clear open source licenses.

Bring Research Closer to Practice

Lead the conversion of promising research in urban planning into applied tools for use by practitioners.

Quality

Ensure tools developed under its guidance meet the most stringent software engineering and quality control standards.

Standards

Encourage the use of open data standards and interoperability across planning tools and related products.

Meta




Governance

The organization has adopted a governance structure similar to the Apache Foundation known for its ability to scale and foster a collaborative meritocracy. Specifically, there are the following units:

OS Planning Board
  • business affairs
  • legal affairs
Project Committees
  • where most work is done



Funding?

Right now this is a completely volunteer and personal-donation-based effort. Into the future, it is anticipated that background organizational costs (i.e. web hosting) will be covered by donations and that the bulk of the work at the project-level will be funded via individual agencies, research institutions or corporations.
